results.title: A Soldier's story [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Caldix Films, Columbia Pictures, Norman Jewison, Ronald L Schwary and Patrick Palmer
results.brief_description: Director Norman Jewison explores themes in “A Soldier’s story” similar to his Academy Award-winning “In the Heat of the Night”. It is World War II and an all black platoon at a Georgia army base spends its time finessing their baseball skills while awaiting the go-ahead to join the war effort. They’re led by the sadistic, incendiary Sergeant Vernon Waters, who rules the platoon with an iron fist and shouts harsh, racist comments even though he himself is an African-American. “A Soldier’s story” begins with the mysterious murder of Waters and then traces the investigation of the crime by black officer, Captain Davenport. Though Davenport suspects two white soldiers of killing Waters, his instincts are proven wrong and the real killer is a dramatic and moving surprise. “A Soldier’s story” is a well-crafted drama that raises the important issue of race relations in America and how racism and discrimination find their way in such official institutions as the military. In fact, the film shows how the military’s power structure supports the abuse of power and iron force rule. Its message overall is bleak: in this microcosmic world of the army, racial discrimination has led to a split in the notion of brotherhood among black men in America with Sergeant Waters internalising and projecting racial conflict on his blood brothers. Cast includes Howard E. Rollins Jr., Adolph Caesar, Art Evans, Denzel Washington and Wings Hauser. Music score by Herbie Hancock.

results.title: A Soldier's daughter never cries
results.creator_credit: Capitol Films, Merchant Ivory Productions, British Screen, Ismail Merchant, Paul Bradley and James Ivory
results.brief_description: Based on the autobiographical novel by Kaylie Jones, daughter of writer James Jones (From here to eternity, A Thin red line), “A Soldier’s daughter never cries” is the story of Channe Willis (Leelee Sobieski), her hard-drinking successful novelist and WWII veteran father, Bill (Kris Kristofferson) and flamboyant poker-player mother, Marcella (Barbara Hershey). The film is divided into three chapters beginning with “Billy” (set in Paris during the 1960s) in which the expatriate American Willis family adopt six-year-old French orphan Benoit (Samuel Gruen) prompting the young Channe to turn to her protective nanny. Once comfortably settled in the family, Benoit asks that his name be changed to Billy. The second chapter “Francis” revolves around a developing relationship between Channe and Francis Fortescue (Anthony Roth Costanzo) who lives with his expatriate British mother (Jane Birkin). However the relationship is threatened when Channe’s father Bill decides to return to America for health reasons - he is suffering from an ailing heart condition. Finally, chapter three “Daddy”, set in North Carolina during the 1970s, explores the father-daughter relationship as young Billy reaches adulthood and Channe becomes more alienated with life. A close intimacy begins to develop between Channe and her bedridden father as she helps him transcribe tapes and type up his manuscript pages for his new novel. Father and daughter share their dreams and thoughts about boys and sex and life and it is this honest and open approach which eventually holds the family together. Contains some French with English subtitles. Cast also includes Dominique Blanc, Jesse Bradford, Virginie Ledoyen, Luisa Conlon.

results.title: A Soho story
results.brief_description: Mac, the busker, who entertained London theatre queues for twenty years, his life and opinions. The narrator’s search for Mac throughout Soho, their meeting, Mac’s reminiscences - his break with his middle-class upbringing, his early days in Soho, a job as a club doorman, his meeting with his wife and their return to busking together, the breakdown of their marriage and his present life as an artist.

results.title: A Skeleton in the crop: the story of skeleton weed (chondrilla juncea) in Australia
results.creator_credit: S.T. Evans, CSIRO and David Corke
results.brief_description: Ever since Skeleton Weed was first discovered in Australia in the early 1900’s, farmers and scientists have been searching for a way to stop it spreading through the wheatlands of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. This is the story of their search. Using archival footage and stills, it tells of the early frustrations over failure to eradicate the weed, the hostility of wheat farmers faced with a problem they did not understand, and their growing appreciation of the role of scientific research in devising the best methods of keeping Skeleton Weed in check.
